Introduction

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) refers to a group of autosomal recessive genetic disorders characterized by a deficient enzyme (eg, 21-hydroxylase, 11Î²-hydroxylase, 17Î±-hydroxylase) in adrenal steroidogenesis.

Adrenal physiology  



The adrenal cortex is composed of 3 layers, each of which produces specific hormones (

figure 1
):



  • Mineralocorticoids (eg, aldosterone):  Regulate sodium and water regulation, which affects blood volume and arterial pressure
  • Glucocorticoids (eg, cortisol):  Mediate the stress response by initiating gluconeogenesis to increase blood glucose, upregulating alpha receptors to increase responsiveness to catecholamines, and suppressessing inflammation
  • Androgens (eg, dehydroepiandrosterone [DHEA], androstenedione):  Sex hormones that lead to virilization and pubic/axillary hair development


Adrenal steroidogenesis involves several enzymes (

figure 2
), and a deficiency in any one of them can impair steroidogenesis; the substrates then accumulate and divert to other pathways.  The clinical presentation can vary depending on which enzyme is deficient and the degree of deficiency (ie, complete deficiency causes severe presentations), as discussed below (
ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
).

21-hydroxylase deficiency: classic CAH 

Pathogenesis and clinical presentation 



21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause of CAH (>95% of cases) (

figure 3
).  21-hydroxylase converts progesterone to 11-deoxycorticosterone (precursor to aldosterone) and 17-hydroxyprogesterone to 11-deoxycortisol (precursor to cortisol).  Complete or near-complete 21-hydroxylase deficiency is known as classic CAH (
ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
), which is characterized by:



  • Decreased mineralocorticoid synthesis:  Results in dehydration with hypotensive shock, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia (ie, salt wasting).  Patients often develop severe vomiting and diarrhea, which can lead to lethargy and failure to thrive. 
  • Decreased glucocorticoid synthesis:  Results in hypoglycemia and hypotension.  Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) secretion is increased (due to lack of negative feedback by cortisol), stimulating adrenal gland hyperplasia. 
  • Increased androgen synthesis:  Without 21-hydroxylase, its substrates (ie, progesterone, 17-hydroxyprogesterone) are diverted to the androgen synthesis pathway, resulting in signs of virilization:
    • 46,XX genotype:  Virilization causes ambiguous genitalia (eg, enlarged clitoris, labial fusion). 
    • 46,XY genotype:  Patients may have subtle findings of hyperandrogenism at birth (eg, enlarged phallus, hyperpigmented scrotum).


Classic CAH can present with varying degrees of salt wasting and virilization, depending on the presence of retained enzymatic activity.  In general, signs of adrenal crisis (ie, hypotensive shock, electrolyte disturbances) develop around age 1-3 weeks, rather than immediately after birth, due to the transient protection of maternal hormones.  Male patients (46,XY) with CAH are more likely to present in adrenal crisis than female patients (46,XX), who are typically identified at birth due to ambiguous genitalia.

Diagnosis 



Patients with classic CAH can be identified by newborn screening, which detects increased serum 17-hydroxyprosterone, a substrate for 21-hydroxylase.  Patients with 46,XX genotype may also have ambiguous genitalia that, along with newborn screening, prompts the diagnosis (patients with 46,XY genotype are asymptomatic at birth).



If not identified by newborn screening, these patients can have life-threatening adrenal crisis and salt wasting at age 1-3-weeks.  Laboratory evaluation during adrenal crisis typically shows hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypoglycemia.  However, prior to the onset of adrenal crisis, serum electrolytes are normal due to the transient protection of maternal hormones.  Additional laboratory testing may include the following:



  • Confirmatory serum testing:  In cases of suspected classic CAH (eg, positive newborn screening, ambiguous genitalia, adrenal crisis), confirmatory serum testing should be obtained; it shows markedly increased serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone and decreased serum cortisol. 
  • ACTH stimulation test:  This is the gold standard for diagnosis.  In CAH, decreased basal cortisol causes increased endogenous ACTH secretion (due to lack of negative feedback by cortisol), and administration of synthetic ACTH (ie, cosyntropin) results in minimal cortisol secretion.  For cases of highly suspected classic CAH (eg, markedly elevated serum 17-hydroxyprogestone, characteristic electrolyte abnormalities, atypical genitalia), ACTH stimulation testing may not be necessary.
  • Karyotype analysis and pelvic ultrasound:  These may be necessary to confirm genotype and assess internal genitalia in patients with ambiguous external genitalia.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for classic CAH includes other diagnoses that present with hypotensive shock or ambiguous genitalia in the neonatal period, including:



  • Galactosemia:  An autosomal recessive disorder in which galactose-1-uridyl transferase deficiency impairs galactose digestion.  Patients vomit after ingestion of breast milk or cow's-milkâ€“based formula and develop hypoglycemia and dehydration, similar to patients with adrenal crisis and salt wasting in classic CAH.  However, patients with galactosemia do not develop hyperkalemia.
  • 5-alpha reductase deficiency:  Impairs the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone and presents in 46,XY patients with undervirilized, ambiguous, or female external genitalia, depending on the presence of retained enzymatic activity.  Serum testosterone is normal, in contrast to patients with classic CAH.
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome:  Characterized by a defective androgen receptor and presents in 46,XY patients with undervirilized, ambiguous, or female external genitalia, depending on the presence of functional receptors.  Serum testosterone is normal, in contrast to patients with classic CAH.
  • Placental aromatase deficiency:  Impairs the conversion of placental androgens into estrogens.  Androgen excess causes virilization in the 46,XX fetus.  Maternal virilization also occurs due to the transplacental transfer of androgens.  Maternal virilization does not occur in classic CAH.

Management



While awaiting confirmatory testing, physiologic glucocorticoid (ie, physiologic-dose hydrocortisone) and mineralocorticoid (ie, fludrocortisone) replacement therapy should be administered to prevent adrenal crisis.  Serum electrolytes should be closely monitored to assess for salt wasting and risk of impending adrenal crisis.  Lifelong physiologic glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement is required to maintain normal blood pressure, electrolytes, and growth and to suppress androgen synthesis (by suppressing ACTH secretion via negative feedback mechanisms).  Sodium supplementation may be required for infants who are not yet eating solid foods.



Patients who present with adrenal crisis require stress-dose hydrocortisone, in addition to volume repletion with isotonic fluids and dextrose to correct hypoglycemia, to prevent morbidity and mortality.  Because hydrocortisone is a potent mineralocorticoid at stress doses, mineralocorticoid replacement is not indicated when stress-dose hydrocortisone is administered.  Stress-dose hydrocortisone may also be necessary during acute illnesses to prevent adrenal crisis.



For 46,XX patients with significant virilization, genital reconstructive surgery may be considered, ideally deferred until the child can participate in decision-making.

21-hydroxylase deficiency: nonclassic CAH

Pathophysiology and clinical presentation 



21-hydroxylase converts progesterone to 11-deoxycorticosterone (precursor to aldosterone) and 17-hydroxyprogesterone to 11-deoxycortisol (precursor to cortisol) (

figure 3
).  Patients with partial 21-hydroxylase deficiency develop milder clinical presentations, referred to as nonclassic (late-onset) CAH (
ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
).  Although mineralocorticoid and glucocorticoid synthesis is decreased in nonclassic CAH, it does not cause adrenal crisis.  Therefore, patients present only with signs of increased androgen synthesis, including signs of precocious puberty, defined as the onset of secondary sexual characteristics in boys age <9 and girls age <8.



In nonclassic CAH, clinical findings are limited to effects of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis causing hyperandrogenism (eg, early onset of pubic hair development [ie, premature pubarche], accelerated growth with advanced bone age, and nodulocystic acne), as opposed to effects of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis (eg, testicular enlargement, breast development).  Additional findings specific for each sex include:



  • Females (46,XX):  These patients may present in adolescence or early adulthood with hirsutism and irregular menses, similar to polycystic ovary syndrome; other findings of virilization (eg, voice deepening, clitoromegaly) are rare.
  • Males (46,XY):  Because the HPG axis is not activated, testicular enlargement does not occur.

Diagnosis 



Because nonclassic CAH often presents with signs of precocious puberty, initial evaluation often includes bone age determination (

figure 5
), which assesses skeletal maturity.  An advanced bone age (ie, skeletal age >2 standard deviations above chronologic age) should prompt further evaluation for the underlying etiology, including CAH.



In these patients, confirmation is with:



  • An increased 17-hydroxyprogesterone level (especially in the early morning).
  • ACTH stimulation test:  May be necessary to confirm the diagnosis in patients with only slightly increased serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone.  An exaggerated 17-hydroxyprogesterone response following ACTH administration is characteristic of nonclassic CAH.


In addition, 21-hydroxylase deficiency is characterized by increased serum renin due to lack of negative feedback by aldosterone and decreased serum luteinizing hormone (LH) due to negative feedback by androgens.

Differential diagnosis 



The differential diagnosis for nonclassic CAH includes other causes of precocious puberty in 46,XY patients, including the following:



  • Central precocious puberty (eg, idiopathic, pituitary microadenoma):  Characterized by premature activation of the HPG axis with increased LH that further increases in response to exogenous GnRH.  In contrast, nonclassic CAH is characterized by decreased LH due to negative feedback by androgens.
  • McCune-Albright syndrome:  A rare cause of peripheral precocious puberty that presents with cafÃ© au lait macules and fibrous dysplasia of bone (eg, bone pain, pathologic fractures); these are not characteristic features of nonclassic CAH.
  • Leydig cell tumor:  A rare cause of excess testosterone and can present with precocious puberty that appears similar to premature activation of the HPG axis (eg, early testicular/phallic enlargement).  A testicular mass is typically palpated on examination.


The differential diagnosis for nonclassic CAH also includes other causes of hyperandrogenism in 46,XX patients (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
), such as:



  • Polycystic ovary syndrome:  The most common cause of hyperandrogenism in reproductive-aged women.  However, it causes an increase in testosterone, not DHEAS, levels.
  • Androgen-secreting tumors (eg, Sertoli-Leydig cell ovarian tumor, adrenal tumor):  Present in women with severe hyperandrogenism and signs of virilization (eg, clitoromegaly, voice deepening) that do not occur in nonclassic CAH.
  • Other endocrine disorders (eg, hyperprolactinemia, Cushing syndrome):  Rare causes of hyperandrogenism in 46,XX patients who typically have more pronounced clinical findings related to the primary endocrinopathy (eg, galactorrhea, cushingoid features).

Management 



The management of nonclassic CAH is based on the patient's genotype:



  • 46,XY patients:  For those with signs of hyperandrogenism and advanced bone maturation (ie, â‰¥2 years advanced), physiologic glucocorticoid replacement therapy is indicated to reduce androgen synthesis and preserve adult height.  Glucocorticoid replacement may be discontinued during puberty, when bone maturation is no longer advanced for the patient's age.
  • 46,XX patients:  Those with signs of hyperandrogenism (eg, irregular menses, hirsutism, nodulocystic acne) in adolescence or early adulthood may require oral contraceptive pills for suppression of ovarian and adrenal androgen synthesis.  Antiandrogen therapy (eg, spironolactone) may be considered for patients with hyperandrogenism that is refractory to treatment with oral contraceptive pills.  In women, these options are preferred over glucocorticoids because they typically require long-term therapy for hirsutism.  Physiologic glucocorticoid replacement should be avoided due to the adverse effects of long-term use (ie, iatrogenic Cushing syndrome).  However, it may be considered for women who cannot tolerate oral contraceptive pills and antiandrogen therapy or who want to become pregnant.


In general, stress-dose glucocorticoid replacement is not required for patients with nonclassic CAH unless the patient has been receiving glucocorticoid replacement and is at risk for hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis suppression.

11Î²-hydroxylase deficiency

Pathophysiology and clinical presentation



11Î²-hydroxylase deficiency is the second most common cause of CAH after 21-hydroxylase deficiency.  11Î²-hydroxylase converts 11-deoxycorticosterone to corticosterone (precursor to aldosterone) and 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol.  Therefore, 11Î²-hydroxylase deficiency results in (

figure 6
):



  • Increased mineralocorticoid synthesis:  11-deoxycorticosterone is a weak mineralocorticoid and, in excess, can cause hypertension and hypokalemia in early childhood.
  • Decreased glucocorticoid synthesis:  11-deoxycortisol is not a biologically active glucocorticoid.  Although patients are at increased risk, adrenal crisis is rare because the excess mineralocorticoid activity of 11-deoxycorticosterone is protective. 
  • Increased androgen synthesis:  The substrates for 11Î²-hydroxylase are diverted to the androgen synthesis pathway, resulting in hyperandrogenism.  Patients typically develop signs of virilization in childhood, similar to nonclassic CAH.  However, in severe cases, there may be signs of virilization at birth, similar to classic CAH.

Diagnosis



Similar to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, minimal cortisol secretion following administration of synthetic ACTH is diagnostic.  11Î²-hydroxylase deficiency is characterized by a significant elevation in 11-deoxycortisol.  Additional findings include decreased serum renin due to negative feedback by 11-deoxycorticosterone (a weak mineralocorticoid) and decreased serum LH due to negative feedback by androgens.

Management 



Management of 11Î²-hydroxylase deficiency may include:



  • Mineralocorticoid blockade:  Drugs that antagonize mineralocorticoid receptors (eg, spironolactone) may be necessary to manage hypertension and hypokalemia. 
  • Glucocorticoid replacement:  Physiologic glucocorticoid replacement is indicated to suppress androgen and mineralocorticoid precursor synthesis. 
  • Management of androgen excess:  Spironolactone may also antagonize both androgen receptors, managing the patient's hyperandrogenism while minimizing glucocorticoid replacement. 

17Î±-hydroxylase deficiency

Pathophysiology and clinical presentation 



17Î±-hydroxylase deficiency  is the least common cause of CAH.  17Î±-hydroxylase converts pregnenolone to 17-hydroxypregnenolone and progesterone to 17-hydroxyprogesterone.  Both of these downstream products are precursors to cortisol and testosterone.  Therefore, 17Î±-hydroxylase deficiency results in (

figure 7
):



  • Increased mineralocorticoid synthesis:  Results in hypertension and hypokalemia in early childhood.
  • Decreased glucocorticoid synthesis:  Decreased cortisol production, but excess corticosterone, which is a weak glucocorticoid.  Therefore, adrenal crises are not seen.
  • Decreased androgen synthesis:  Results in delayed pubarche with minimal pubic and axillary hair.  In addition:
    • Females (46,XX):  17Î±-hydroxylase is involved in sex hormone synthesis in the adrenal glands and gonads.  Because androgens are estrogen precursors, estrogen is also deficient, resulting in absent secondary sexual characteristics (eg, pubertal breast development).  Patients also have primary amenorrhea in adolescence.
    • Males (46,XY):  In severe cases, decreased androgen synthesis results in female external genitalia at birth (ie, blind vaginal pouch) without female internal genitalia, similar to androgen insensitivity syndrome.  In milder cases, patients may have undervirilized, ambiguous genitalia.

Diagnosis 



Administration of synthetic ACTH results in minimal cortisol secretion, similar to other forms of CAH.  17Î±-hydroxylase deficiency is characterized by decreased serum renin due to negative feedback by aldosterone.  In contrast to 21-hydroxylase deficiency and 11Î²-hydroxylase deficiency, 17Î±-hydroxylase deficiency is characterized by increased serum LH due to lack of negative feedback by androgens.



In all forms of CAH, genetic testing can identify the exact mutation, which confirms the diagnosis and informs counseling for future pregnancies.

Management



Management of 17Î±-hydroxylase deficiency may include:



  • MIneralocorticoid blockade:  Spironolactone may be necessary to antagonize mineralocorticoid receptors and thereby manage hypertension and hypokalemia. 
  • Glucocorticoid replacement:  Physiologic cortisol replacement can help suppress mineralocorticoid precursor synthesis. 
  • Sex steroid (ie, estrogen, testosterone) replacement therapy:  This may be considered, depending on the patient's identified gender and goals of therapy.

Prognosis



The prognosis for patients with CAH, regardless of the deficient enzyme, is favorable with prompt diagnosis and treatment.  For patients with classic CAH, compliance with lifelong glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement therapy is essential.  With close monitoring and dose adjustments, patients can achieve normal growth, reproductive function (eg, puberty, regular menstruation), and life expectancy.  However, there is an increased risk of mortality in early childhood due to adrenal crisis following acute illness.  Education regarding initiation of stress-dosing at the onset of an acute illness is required to prevent complications.

Summary



Congenital adrenal hyperplasia refers to a group of autosomal recessive genetic disorders in which a mutation in the gene that encodes the enzyme 21-hydroxylase, 11Î²-hydroxylase, or 17Î±-hydroxylase results in reduced or absent enzymatic activity and impaired glucocorticoid synthesis.  Depending on the affected enzyme, there may be signs of mineralocorticoid and androgen deficiency or excess.  Management involves glucocorticoid replacement therapy in severe cases, with close monitoring and dose adjustments to achieve normal growth and reproductive function while minimizing the adverse effects of long-term glucocorticoid use.
